verses.verse: (1 Here he complaineth to God of the cruel pride and arrogance of Saul, and the rest of his enemies, who thus raged without any cause given on his part.6 Therefore he desireth God to revenge his innocence and deliver him. ) Hear the right, O Lord, consider my cry: hearken unto my prayer of lips unfeigned.
Let my (The vengeance that thou shalt show against mine enemies.) sentence come forth from thy presence, and let thine eyes behold equity.

Thou hast (When thy Spirit examined my conscience.) proved and visited mine heart in the night: thou hast tried me, and foundest nothing: for I was purposed that my (I was innocent toward mine enemy both in deed and thought.) mouth should not offend.
Concerning the works of men, by the (Though the wicked provoked me to do evil for evil, yet thy word kept me back.) words of thy lips I kept me from the paths of the cruel man.
Stay my steps in thy paths, that my feet do not slide.
I have called upon thee: (He was assured that God would not refuse his request.) surely thou wilt hear me, O God: incline thine ear to me, and hearken unto my words.
Show thy marvelous mercies: thou that art the Savior of them that trust in thee, from such as (For all rebel against thee, which trouble thy Church.) resist thy right hand.
Keep me as the apple of the eye: hide me under the shadow of thy wings,
From the wicked that oppress me, from mine enemies, which compass me round about for (For their cruelty cannot be satisfied but with my death.) my soul.
They are enclosed in their own (They are puffed up with pride, as the stomach that is choked with fat.) fat, and they have spoken proudly with their mouth.
They have compassed us now in our steps: they have set their eyes to bring down to the ground:
Like as a lion that is greedy of prey, and as it were a Lion’s whelp lurking in secret places.
Up Lord, (Stop his rage.) disappoint him: cast him down: deliver my soul from the wicked (Or, which is thy sword.) with thy sword,

From men by thine (By thine heavenly power.) hand, O Lord, from men (Or, whose tyranny hath too long endured.) of the world, who have their (And feel not the smart that God’s children oft times do.) portion in this life, whose bellies thou fillest with thine hid treasure: their children have enough, and leave the rest of their substance for their children.

But I will behold thy face (This is the full felicity, comforting against all assaults, to have the face of God and favorable countenance opened unto us.) in righteousness, and when I (And am delivered out of my great troubles.) wake, I shall be satisfied with thine image.
